metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Title: Reply to: Skin damage among healthcare workers managing coronavirus disease-2019

abstract.text: This article does not have an abstract to display.

body_text.text: We were pleased to read Lan et al.'s letter on the characteristics of skin damage due to personal protective equipment (PPE) during the COVID-19 pandemic. 1 They reported that 97.0% (n=526/546) of health care workers (HCWs) experienced cutaneous adverse events due to PPE, commonly on the nasal bridge (83.1%) and cheeks (78.7%). Although mild and self-limited, damages to the skin should not be overlooked as they can lead to an increased risk of contracting COVID-19. The associated symptoms of burning, itching or stinging can predispose HCWs to face touching behaviour, which has been implicated in viral transmission. 2 We believe that these PPE-associated cutaneous complications should not be overlooked. In this letter, we propose practical strategies that can be implemented by HCWs to mitigate cutaneous complications to various PPEs (see Table 1 ).

The additives (e.g., formaldehyde textile resins) added to fibers of "scrubs/greens" can lead to textile allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). 3 It is reported that 22.8% of the general population is sensitive to formaldehyde and this complication can be exacerbated by friction, moisture from perspiration, warmth, and tight-fitting clothing. 3 To mitigate these effects, clinical environments should be maintained at adequate low temperatures, and HCWs should avoid wearing tight garments whenever possible.

Up to 99% of PPE-related cutaneous reactions are due to gloves as prolonged use can lead to allergic contact dermatitis, overhydration, and subsequent skin maceration and erosion. 4 To avoid overhydration, one layer of gloves is recommended. Other types of gloves to consider include nitrile or vinyl gloves, if available. Application of hand creams, or hydrophobic compress with normal saline or topical zinc ointment after completing clinical duties can mitigate skin maceration. 4 One study reports that 59.6% of HCWs who regularly used N95 masks during the SARS pandemic developed facial acne while 35.8% of HCWs developed a facial rash from either ICD or ACD. 5 Similarly, prolonged goggle wear has led to urticaria, pressure injury, contact dermatitis, and acne vulgaris in HCWs. 4 Masks and goggles should be well-fitted to reduce pressure injuries, and when possible, full-face shields can replace facial PPE. Facial moisturizers or gels should be applied before wearing facial PPE. Severe skin indentation can be managed with hydropathic compress and povidone iodine diluted by normal saline at a ratio of 1:9 on the face. 4 Some facial masks are secured by anchoring to the ears, causing damage to the external ears and retroauricular skin areas due to pressure and/or prolonged exposure. 4 To avoid damage, we recommended wearing ear-independent masks when possible, covering retroauricular areas with a surgical cap prior to wearing ear-dependent PPE, clean and drying the external ear and canal and applying moisturizers to retroauricular skin.
An increase in the rigorous use of PPE by HCWs since the COVID-19 outbreak has presented unique dermatological challenges related to PPE-associated pressure and abrasion injuries.

Although strict adherence to PPE guidelines is paramount in reducing the spread of infection, measures should be implemented to protect the skin barrier -thereby, preventing the paradoxical situation in which protection measures become a risk for COVID-19 infection.

TABREF0.text: Recommendations for Preventing Personal Protective Equipment-Associated Cutaneous Complications. Application of hand creams, hydrophobic compress with normal saline or topical zinc ointment following shift • Moisturize hands regularly, and ensure hands are clean and dry prior to putting on gloves • Avoid wearing hand and wrist jewelry, as well as nail polish and artificial nails • Use nitrile or vinyl gloves • Keep nails short and filed N95 masks and goggles • Use full-face shields if cutaneous complications are present • Ensure well-fitted and not tight • Apply facial moisturizers and gels prior to wearing facial PPE • Apply hydropathic compress to damaged skin Ear protection • Clean and dry external ear and canal after taking off PPE • Cover retroauricular areas with surgical cap prior to putting on ear PPE • Treat retroauricular skin with hydropathic compress following shift • Wear N95 mask with plastic handle
